data.title: DeadCode: Remove MonoLive service code
data.body:
There is a MonoLive and MonoLiveClient class in GamerServices that point to monolive.com, which is a deadend domain. I conversed with @migueldeicaza about this and there is no MonoLive service related to gamer services.

This code should be put into the attic.

data.title: Simple Effect Fixes
data.body:
A pair of simple Effect fixes:
- Removed bogus assert on null shaders in EffectPass constructor.
- Fixed bug where wrong shader could be assigned to a multipass effect.

This cannot break any of the platforms.

data.title: Fixed TextInput Crash
data.body: Simple crash fix on null TextInput event in GameWindow.

data.title: Content.Load<Model> messes with my effect lighting
data.body:
In my Game class, I use the Initialize method to set up my lighting, including setting my effect object's DirectionalLight0 properties. I set the DirectionalLight0.DiffuseColor and .SpecularColor both to White, and these colours are applied to the objects that I render in my game.

Then I add a call to Content.Load<Model> in my LoadContent method. Just by doing this, all the lights go out, and everything in the game appears as a black silhouette. If I query the DirectionalLight0.DiffuseColor and .SpecularColor after calling Content.Load, they both still report themselves as being white, but if I then actually assign white to them again, the lights switch back on.

I've worked around this for now by adding the following code to the end of my LoadContent method:

```
_effect.DirectionalLight0.DiffuseColor = _effect.DirectionalLight0.DiffuseColor;
_effect.DirectionalLight0.SpecularColor = _effect.DirectionalLight0.SpecularColor;
```

i.e., setting the light colours to be their existing values. This resolves the problem. I'm not sure why loading a model is causing my lights to stop working, but it'd be great if they didn't do this.

An example of this can be seen in the example project here: http://adamdawes.com/private/MonoGameXFile.zip . The code as provided displays the model as a totally black silhouette. By adding the lines of code shown above to the end of the LoadContent method (after the call to Content.Load), the lighting begins to work again. (Ignore the fact that the texture doesn't appear and there's a hole in the house model, those are separate issues.)

Tested against MonoGame 3.0.0.0 in Windows 8 and Windows Phone 8.

data.title: GraphicsDevice.SamplerStates[0] defaults to null, whereas in XNA it defaults to SamplerState.LinearWrap
data.body:
As I have documented at great length at http://monogame.codeplex.com/discussions/435349 I have spent several days battling to get textures to display on a model loaded using Content.Load<Model>. I eventually tracked this down to the default state of the GraphicsDevice.SamplerStates array.

In XNA 4.0, GraphicsDevice.SamplerStates[0] is set to SamplerState.LinearWrap by the time the Game class's Initialize method is called. I have an old set of MonoGame source code on my hard drive which also defaults SamplerStates[0] to the same value.

In the current MonoGame source code (retrieved from GitHub a few days ago), SamplerStates[0] is null when Initialize is called. This is the same for the v3.0.0.0 binaries. As a result, my model textures (which are not in the range of 0..1 on either axis) were being clamped and not rendered properly.

Now that I understand the problem, I can simply configure SamplerStates[0] myself in my Initialize method, but as this is not the same behaviour as XNA itself, I would like to propose that this be changed to default to a LinearWrap state. This has had me tearing my hair out for several days, it may well affect others too. (I've experienced this with MonoGame on both Windows 8 and Windows Phone 8.)

data.title: Fixed byte order for Texture2D.GetData to ARGB on Android
data.body:
see http://developer.android.com/reference/android/graphics/Bitmap.html and http://developer.android.com/reference/android/graphics/Color.html

the latter states that the order should be ARGB:
(alpha << 24) | (red << 16) | (green << 8) | blue

Detected the wrong order when developing a screenshot (& mail) module for a current game project... 

NB: sorry for the (unnecessary) additional change on line 597, my VS converted the tabs to spaces...

data.body:
This PR adds the unit and functional tests back into the main repository.   The originals are here:

data.body:
We need to finalize the coding style guidelines in this document:

This is a required step before we can do #1511.

Lets keep all discussion in this thread before any PRs are submitted to change the guide.

data.title: Fix Coding Style And Formatting
data.body:
Use an automated tool to apply the [MonoGame code style guidelines](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/wiki/Coding-Guidelines) to all C# code.

We will use a special user account... either @mgbot or a new @mgwhitespace account to do the commit so that no ones personal account is attributed all the changes in the project stats.
#1512 must be completed before this task can begin.

data.title: Fixed exception when loading a song before the MediaManager is initialised, and added called to Shutdown() on game exit.
data.body:
I was getting a SharpDXException (see below) when calling `Content.Load<Song>(...)`.

(WindowsDX)

The cause was that the `MediaManager.StartUp(...)` call was only being done in the static constructor of the MediaPlayer, this meant if the Song was loaded before the MediaPlayer was used an exception was thrown.

I've added a MediaManagerState class to control the startup to ensure it only gets started once, and I've also added a shutdown call to the Game class.

Full exception details:

```
SharpDX.SharpDXException was unhandled
  HResult=-1072873851
  Message=HRESULT: [0xC00D3E85], Module: [Unknown], ApiCode: [Unknown/Unknown], Message: Unknown
  Source=SharpDX
  StackTrace:
       at SharpDX.Result.CheckError()
       at SharpDX.MediaFoundation.SourceResolver.CreateObjectFromURL(String wszURLRef, Int32 dwFlags, ComObject propsRef, ObjectType& objectTypeRef, ComObject& objectOut)
       at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Media.Song.GetTopology() in c:\Development\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Media\Song.cs:line 197
       at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Media.Song..ctor(String fileName) in c:\Development\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Media\Song.cs:line 90
       at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Media.Song..ctor(String fileName, Int32 durationMS) in c:\Development\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Media\Song.cs:line 73
       at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.SongReader.Read(ContentReader input, Song existingInstance) in c:\Development\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Content\ContentReaders\SongReader.cs:line 93
       at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentTypeReader`1.Read(ContentReader input, Object existingInstance) in c:\Development\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Content\ContentTypeReader.cs:line 185
       at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentReader.ReadObject[T]() in c:\Development\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Content\ContentReader.cs:line 217
       at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentReader.ReadAsset[T]() in c:\Development\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Content\ContentReader.cs:line 100
        at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentManager.ReadAsset[T](String assetName, Action`1 recordDisposableObject) in c:\Development\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Content\ContentManager.cs:line 289
       at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentManager.Load[T](String assetName) in c:\Development\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\Content\ContentManager.cs:line 212
       at TestApp.TestGame.Initialize() in c:\Development\TestApp\TestGame.cs:line 106
```

data.title: Mac textinput

data.title: Cannot find symbol  __FastDevLauncher
data.body:
Hey there.

I just downloaded the latest libraries (3.0.1) and my olution immediately started getting the following build error:

```
....\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework\obj\Debug\android\src\mono\TrialSplashScreen3d6367dc2927431db9f9fff402e45c96.java(101,101): Error:  cannot find symbol

symbol  : class __FastDevLauncher

location: package mono.android

                Intent intent = new Intent (TrialSplashScreen3d6367dc2927431db9f9fff402e45c96.this, mono.android.__FastDevLauncher.class);

 (MonoGame.Framework.Android)
```

This is in Xamarin Studio (they also released an update today) with a 30 day trial of Xamarin Android, building the source for the MonoGame framework inside my project.

I should say that when I originally started porting I got this error in MonoGame 3.0.0. I was using the libraries installed on my machine and referencing the .DLLs in my project. I the GitHub discussion about the HotFix mentioning linker errors and tried building the source with my solution, which removed the error.

Has anybody else seen this?

Cheers

Chris

P.S. Downloading the latest source from GitHub, loading the MonoGame.Framework.Android solution, and building gives the same error for me without any modifications.

data.title: BlendState.ColorWriteChannels is ignored (Windows OpenGL)
GraphicsDevice.PresentationParameters.BackBufferWidth incorrect in Game.Initialize
GraphicsDeviceManager.PreferredDepthStencilFormat ignored (Windows OpenGL)
data.body:
In VS 2010, create new "MonoGame Windows OpenGL Project".

In the Game's constructor have this:

```
        graphics = new GraphicsDeviceManager(this);
        graphics.PreferredDepthStencilFormat = DepthFormat.Depth24Stencil8;
```

Run the game and in the Initialize function, check the following in the debugger:

```
        this.GraphicsDevice.PresentationParameters.DepthStencilFormat
```

The value will be Depth24 instead of Depth24Stencil8 (and I verified that stencil operations do not work). I am able to create a RenderTarget2D with DepthFormat.Depth24Stencil8 though.

Note: I tried specifying DepthFormat.None also, and that was also ignored. It seems the back buffer is always Depth24.

I'm using MonoGame 3.0.1.

data.title: Call OnExiting From Game.Exit()
data.body:
Currently when you call `Game.Exit()` on any MonoGame platform the `Game.OnExiting` method is not fired.

We should fix this as well as test to see what other methods/events are triggered from `Game.Exit()`.

Note it should only work on platforms where Game.Exit() is valid...  on platforms where it is not we should throw an exception and not call back any methods/events.

data.title: Fixing PowerOfTwo SpriteFont crash on iOS
data.body:
Fixed a bug in the SpriteFont processor. For iOS the underlying texture has to be power of two and square, the content processor only checked if the texture was square.  This bug has been reported in the past, and people have been avoiding it by just playing with fonts and font sizes.  @see http://monogame.codeplex.com/discussions/404006 for an instance of how the bug shows itself when running on iOS.

Make sure when reproducing the problem you have to be running with a debug build of monogame or the opengl error wont be checked for.

data.title: WPF interop support for Windows/DirectX.
data.body:
This pull request adds WPF interop support for MonoGame to show graphics in a WPF D3DImage. 

Notable changes:
Added support for Bgr32 and Bgra32 surface formats.
Added support to created a "shared" render target.
Changed the GraphicsDevice constructor. (This is necessary because in WPF projects we want to create GraphicsDevice instances without using the GraphicsDeviceManager. This was not possible because the internal method GraphicsDevice.Initialize() had to be called.)

We will provide a sample which shows how to use MonoGame in WPF.

We have tested the interop in our WPF projects for a while and it seems to work fine.

data.title: wav files won't play on android
data.body:
I've tried for a few days now to get wav files to play on android. (Testing on a 4.2.2 Nexus 7) I have the latest versions of mono from github. I'm doing your standard load content and SoundEffect.Play. I debugged the play event down and it seems that when it tries to play it's reporting that the soundpool is not ready.. which I don't know how to fix.
At one point for no reason I can discern the sounds worked so I uninstalled and redeployed but they haven't worked since. 
The effect definitely contains byte data from the wav, and they are all very small wav files (100kb or less) I've completely exhausted google. Any help would be greatly appreciated.

data.title: [WindowsGL] Everything using shaders draws red only
data.body:
I'm using some simple bloom shaders and on one of my 4 PC's, everything is drawn red. This is what it looks like on 3 of them: (and as it should)
![Normal](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/598131/218541/8a4d4bf8-850c-11e2-8e44-b34c3f61817b.jpg)

And this is what it looks like on my best PC:
![Red](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/598131/218551/c3ce96e8-850c-11e2-91fa-685662d6b04e.jpg)

The unusual thing is that those shaders have been working for weeks. I've spent DAYS trying to find out why it is doing that but nothing. I even reinstalled windows in a desperate act to finally fix the damned thing...no luck.

I've gone forward and back on graphics card drivers, no luck. The video card is an Nvidia 660ti. 

Here is my DxDiag: http://dl.dropbox.com/u/33510174/DxDiag.txt
Here is the program: http://dl.dropbox.com/u/33510174/Conquer.rar

EDIT: Oh and I'm using TortoiseSVN to sync up everything between PC's so I know they are all using the same copy.
EDIT 2: Also no other games appear to be affected by this. I've played 2d and 3d games of all types and they display as they should.
EDIT 3: I converted the project back to XNA and it runs as it should on all computers.

XNA:
![XNA](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/598131/218893/7837a1f0-8518-11e2-9b03-677a7bb5cb34.jpg)

data.title: XAudio2 might be started on a worker thread

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body:
XAudio2.StartEngine() must be called on the main thread.  The static constructor for SoundEffect is called on the first use of the SoundEffect class.  If this first use is on a worker thread, the static constructor is run in the context of the worker thread and XAudio2.StartEngine() will be called on the worker thread.

I have a pending solution for this (invoking the StartEngine call back to the main thread), but it's not properly working yet.  Raising this issue so it's not forgotten.

data.title: Fixing SoundEffect.Play so that it sends the default pitch in Xna, 0.0f....
data.body: ...  The old value of 1, caused extremely high pitched sounds in Xna on iOS and SoundEffectInstance already uses 0 as the default.

data.title: [Android] No Launchable Activity
Removed unnecessary garbage generation in Model.Draw
data.body:
Problem: Model.Draw method was generating considerable amount of unnecessary garbage by allocating new bone transform array with every call to the method.

Solution: New static field was introduced which replaces the role of bone transforms array. This array is static in order to save memory. We do not need separate instance for each Model because the transforms are set always directly before drawing the Model. At each Draw method call, the array is checked for null and if it is long enough to hold transforms for Model with highest number of bones.
